resources.string: Large expanse of salty basin floor, lowest point, sometimes rough terrain.
11,00\' peak with a beautiful view, one hell of a climb to get there.
Soon after Paradise Cafe this is lovely spring water. A beautiful hidden treasure right of the road, a bit of a scramble out.
Abandoned shack, a small pool with goldfish! Water tastes very fishy, drink at your own risk.
Abandoned mining town, very cool! Sometimes the owner will be there giving a tour, if so there you can ask for water. Caching water here is possible if vehicle can make it up the road.
tricky decent from the Inyo Mountains, pick your route carefully.
Summit of Mt Whitney (14,505\'), southern terminus of the John Muir Trail (western terminus of L2H).
Bring some water in the car to fill your initial capacity. Initial food supply.
First trail town, great burgers, spot to camp. Cache food here, there is very limited food to buy at the store. Reliable water.
Real town, lots of water and food. There is a nice man at the gear shop who may let you cache gear here if you ask before hand.
Busy Campground, lots of fresh water and a small store.
The first road after the salt flats.
The first canyon has a spring, right before you climb to telescope ridge. Before you begin your trek, call the ranger station and check if the spring is flowing.
The second spring is in Tuber canyon, after you drop of the ridge.
Crossing the highway at Saline Valley Rd; leave some water here on your way to the start.
Possible spring depending on snow melt.
Very unreliable spring, often hard to get to. Can be hard to find in the slot canyons.
Long dirt road, possible cache site. Road is possible for most vehicles
Small campground outside of town. Reliable spigots and bathrooms.
Nice little creek on the Whitney portal trail.
Many a lake on the climb to whitney, for both the mountaineers route and main Mt. Whiney trail.
